title: 105_hr1160
content: The "Federal Reserve Audit and Accountability Act" allows the President to appoint Federal Reserve Bank Presidents with Senate consent. The "Federal Reserve Audit and Accountability Act" allows the President to appoint Federal Reserve Bank Presidents and 1st Vice Presidents for 5-year terms. The President appoints bank presidents with Senate consent, while each bank's president appoints a 1st vice president. The bank president serves as the chief executive officer, and the 1st vice president has additional duties. The first vice president of a Federal Reserve Bank serves as the chief executive officer in the absence or disability of the president or during a vacancy. Vacancies in the office of president or first vice president are filled in accordance with the original appointment process. The first appointment of the president for each Federal Reserve Bank takes place upon the expiration of the term of the current president. The term of the first vice president of any Federal Reserve Bank appointed before the enactment of this Act will end when a new president is appointed. The appointment process for the first vice president will follow the amendment made by subsection (a). The subdivision designated "Fifth" of the 4th paragraph of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to make all executive officers and employees of the bank directly responsible to the president of the bank. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require GAO audits of the Federal Reserve Board and Federal Reserve Banks, along with the submission of itemized budgets. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to require GAO audits of the Federal Reserve Board and Banks, including restrictions on auditing certain transactions involving foreign entities. Additionally, a new subsection is added for auditing Federal Reserve System vault facilities. The Comptroller General of the United States audits Federal Reserve vault facilities every 3 years to ensure proper internal controls are in place. They also review independent auditors' reports for accuracy and report any significant issues discovered. The Comptroller General audits Federal Reserve vault facilities every 3 years to ensure internal controls. The audit reports are submitted to the Board of Governors, Inspector General, and relevant congressional committees. During the first 15 days of each regular session of Congress, the estimated receipts and proposed expenditures of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and all Federal Reserve Banks for the following fiscal year and the 2 succeeding fiscal years shall be transmitted to Congress. The budget shall meet the same requirements as the budget of the United States Government. Public disclosure of Open Market Committee meetings is required. Section 12A of the Federal Reserve Act is amended to require prompt public disclosures of meetings of the Federal Open Market Committee, including maintaining verbatim transcripts and disclosing policy actions within a year of the meeting. The Federal Reserve Act now mandates timely public disclosure of Federal Open Market Committee decisions and directives, with limited redaction authority for verbatim transcripts. Compliance audits are overseen by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to periodically audit the Board's compliance with disclosure requirements for Federal Open Market Committee transcripts. All transcripts from meetings held over a year before the enactment of the Federal Reserve Audit and Accountability Act must be made public by December 31, 1997. The definition of a "meeting" includes executive sessions and informal gatherings with a quorum of committee members present. SEC. 23. PRESIDENTIALLY APPOINTED INSPECTOR GENERAL FOR FEDERAL RESERVE SYSTEM. Amendments to the Inspector General Act of 1978 include adding the Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System to the list of entities covered by the Act. Additionally, a new section is added concerning special provisions concerning the Federal Reserve Board. The Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may delegate authority to the Vice Chairman but not to any other officer or employee. The Inspector General of the Board of Governors may select and employ necessary officers and employees for the Office of Inspector General, subject to applicable laws and regulations. The Inspector General of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System has authority over the conditions, operations, and facilities of the Federal reserve banks. Additionally, the position of Inspector General is placed at Level IV of the Executive Schedule. There is a transition period for current service, with exceptions as provided by law. The current Inspector General of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System can continue in their position until a successor is appointed by the President or up to 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The term "successor" may include the individual currently holding the position.
